content: Each frontier model currently has a lifespan of approximately two months at the technological frontier.
A frontier model costing $1B for research and training and $1B for inference can generate over $4B in revenues while it remains at the frontier, resulting in a net profit exceeding $2B.
Exponential increases in frontier AI training costs cannot continue indefinitely due to real-world capacity constraints and diminishing returns on capability improvements.
An "equilibrium" state will eventually be reached in frontier AI development where training costs diminish, and improvements are driven more efficiently by algorithmic advances.

The AI industry is currently in a state of market concentration with a few dominant players in frontier AI, largely due to the order of magnitude cost increase in model training and commensurate improvement in capabilities.
AI labs will resemble cloud providers from a business perspective in the post-scaling era.
The post-scaling era for AI labs will likely maintain a large barrier to entry due to massive upfront capital requirements, similar to cloud providers.

Top AI models may be much more differentiated than largely undifferentiated cloud providers, as evidenced by variations in strengths and personalities observed in Claude, ChatGPT, and Gemini over the past 6-8 months.
